Knowledge Point: Inserted Spanish constituents belong to various word classes, but the insertion of content words, and nouns in particular, prevails. Thus we find novio ‘fiancé’ and pueblo ‘village’ in \REF{ex:key:1696}. Note that both Spanish nouns are objects\is{objects} of Pichi elements, the first of a verb, the second of a preposition:
Content 1: \gll Mék yu nó sé yu dɔ́n gɛ́t \textbf{novio} na \textbf{pueblo}, na kɔ́ntri. | \gls SBJV 2SG know QUOT 2SG PRF get boyfriend LOC village LOC country | \glt ‘You should know that you already have a fiancé in the village, in the hometown.

Knowledge Point: When Spanish nouns are inserted as in \REF{ex:key:1696}, they usually remain bare where Pichi nouns do so, or are accompanied by Pichi determiners and the pluraliser\is{pluraliser} dɛn ‘\textsc{pl’} in the same way as Pichi nouns are. In \REF{ex:key:1697}, the definite Spanish noun paciencia ‘patience’ is preceded by the Pichi definite article di: \is{article}
Content 1: \gll Mék yu nó sé yu dɔ́n gɛ́t \textbf{novio} na \textbf{pueblo}, na kɔ́ntri. | \gls SBJV 2SG know QUOT 2SG PRF get boyfriend LOC village LOC country | \glt ‘You should know that you already have a fiancé in the village, in the hometown.
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Porque} fɔ́s, di \textbf{paciencia}, yu nó go gɛ́t=an. | \gls because first DEF patience 2SG NEG POT get=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘Because first, the patience, you wouldn’t have it.’

Knowledge Point: When a specific Spanish plural noun is inserted, there is a strong likelihood that it will be additionally marked with the postposed Pichi pluraliser dɛn, in accordance with the pattern that applies to Pichi count nouns \REF{ex:key:1698}. Conversely, Spanish nouns exhibit a strong tendency to occur devoid of Pichi number and definiteness\is{definiteness} marking where the noun is non-specific as with rallador ‘grater’ in the second example:
Content 1: \gll \'{A}fta una báy di \textbf{bloques} \textbf{dɛn} tumára. | \gls then 2PL buy DEF bricks PL tomorrow | \glt ‘Then you [plural] buy the bricks tomorrow.’

Knowledge Point: The occurrence of pruebas ‘proofs’ in \REF{ex:key:1700} demonstrates that Spanish nouns may well be devoid of Pichi noun phrase marking, but not necessarily so of the Spanish plural morpheme \{\textit{{}-s}\}:
Content 1: \gll Yu go gɛ́t \textbf{prueba-s}. | \gls 2SG POT get proof-PL | \glt ‘You will have proof.’

Knowledge Point: This is not surprising however, since in Spanish, determiner-less plural count nouns may have non-specific reference. The semantic overlap between Spanish plural nouns and Pichi bare nouns in codemixing can be seen in \REF{ex:key:1701}. Here the Pichi bare nouns pía ‘avocado’ and sadín ‘sardine’ are functionally equivalent to the Spanish plural noun tomates ‘tomatoes’:
Content 1: \gll Mí wet Rubi wi mék jwɛn-jwɛ́n, wi báy pía, wi báy sadín, wi báy \textbf{tomates}, wi \textbf{desayuna}. | \gls 1SG.INDP with NAME 1PL make RED.CPD{}-join 1PL buy avocado 1PL buy sardine 1PL buy tomatoes 1PL have.breakfast | \glt ‘Me and Rubi, we teamed up and bought avocados, we bought sardines, we bought tomatoes, we had breakfast.’

Knowledge Point: The insertion of larger nominal groups as opposed to single nouns is rarer. In fact, most of the Spanish adjective-noun combinations we encounter are collocations that are somewhat lexicalised in Spanish. Compare traducción directa ‘direct translation’ in \REF{ex:key:1702}:
Content 1: \gll Na \textbf{traducción} \textbf{directa} e mék. | \gls FOC translation direct 3SG.SBJ make | \glt ‘It’s a direct translation that she made.’

Knowledge Point: The order of constituents normally remains unchanged when Spanish elements are inserted into a Pichi NP. In \REF{ex:key:1703}, the Pichi quantifier\is{quantifiers} lás ‘last’ is used in prenominal position with the inserted Spanish noun semana ‘week’. However, note that Spanish also features a quantifier + noun order in NPs (i.e. la última semana ‘(the) last week’):
Content 1: \gll Ɛf yu bin kán bigín \textbf{las} \textbf{semana} yu bin fɔ dɔ́n fínis tidé. | \gls if 2SG PST PFV begin last week 2SG PST COND PRF finish today | \glt ‘If you had begun last week you would have been finished today.’

Knowledge Point: There is, however, some variation, although it is not all that frequent. In \REF{ex:key:1704}, the Spanish adjective directo ‘direct’ occurs after the Pichi noun ɔnkúl ‘uncle’ in a Pichi NP and thereby follows the constituent order of a Spanish \textsc{NP}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:1705}, we find the opposite situation. The Spanish adjective especial ‘special’ is in a prenominal position, hence in the syntactic slot of attributively used Pichi property items:
Content 1: \gll E bríng fís, e kúk sɔn \textbf{especial} fís, e gí mí mék a chɔ́p. | \gls 3SG.SBJ bring fish 3SG.SBJ cook some special fish 3SG.SBJ give 1SG.INDP SBJV 1SG.SBJ eat | \glt ‘She brought (a) fish, she cooked a particular fish and gave it to me in order to eat.’

Knowledge Point: There are other instances of Spanish adjectives that follow Pichi nouns in Pichi NPs. But in these cases, the function of the Spanish words parallels that of some Pichi value property items that are used as adverbials in the same syntactic position. The Spanish adjective serio ‘serious’ in \REF{ex:key:1706} may be likened to the Pichi manner adverb fáyn ‘well, really’ in \REF{ex:key:1707}:
Content 1: \gll Dí wán go tɔ́n plába \textbf{serio}. | \gls this one POT turn trouble serious | \glt ‘This will turn into real trouble.’
Content 2: \gll ‘Dí mán dé trɔ́n’ nó dé fáyn, e nó gɛ́t \textbf{sentido} fáyn. | \gls this man BE.LOC strong NEG BE.LOC fine 3SG.SBJ NEG get meaning fine | \glt ‘“Dí man dé trɔn” is not nice, it doesn’t have a proper meaning.’

Knowledge Point: The admixture of Spanish verbs follows established rules. Spanish verbs are always inserted into Pichi clauses in an invariant form of the \textsc{3sg} person of the Spanish present tense\is{present tense} paradigm. This insertion rule is valid without exception across the three regular Spanish verb inflection classes. Due to its frequency, the \textsc{3sg} present tense form is also the default form found in most contact scenarios involving Spanish (\citealt[20–21]{Clements2009}). Examples follow with controla ‘control’ (<controlar) in \REF{ex:key:1709}, entiende ‘understand’ (<entender) in \REF{ex:key:1710}, and sufre ‘suffer’ (<sufrir) in \REF{ex:key:1711}:
Content 1: \gll Frɔn na yá só dɛn kin \textbf{controla} di húman. | \gls from LOC here like.that 3PL HAB control DEF woman | \glt ‘From here they control the woman.’
Content 2: \gll Pɔ́sin go \textbf{entiende} bɔt e nó dé \textbf{bien}. | \gls person POT understand but 3SG.SBJ NEG BE.LOC good | \glt ‘One would understand but it isn’t good.’
Content 3: \gll E \textbf{sufre} wé náw dɛn dɔ́n lɛ́f=an, e dɔ́n klós. | \gls 3SG.SBJ suffer SUB now 3PL PRF leave=3SG.OBJ 3SG.SBJ PRF close | \glt ‘It [the building] suffered, while now they have abandoned it, it is closed.’

Knowledge Point: The \textsc{3sg} invariant form is combined with Pichi TMA markers like any Pichi verb as can be seen by the presence of kin ‘\textsc{hab}’ in \REF{ex:key:1709} and go ‘\textsc{pot}’ in \REF{ex:key:1710} above. Inserted Spanish verbs may also be reduplicated by the same derivational process that applies to Pichi verbs. Compare pica-píca ‘\textsc{red}.\textsc{cpd}{}-cut.up’ = ‘repeatedly cut up (into small pieces)’ in \REF{ex:key:1712}:
Content 1: \gll Frɔn na yá só dɛn kin \textbf{controla} di húman. | \gls from LOC here like.that 3PL HAB control DEF woman | \glt ‘From here they control the woman.’
Content 2: \gll Pɔ́sin go \textbf{entiende} bɔt e nó dé \textbf{bien}. | \gls person POT understand but 3SG.SBJ NEG BE.LOC good | \glt ‘One would understand but it isn’t good.’
Content 3: \gll A bigín de \textbf{pica}\textit{{}-}\textbf{píca}, wi fráy \textbf{patata}, wi fráy plantí. | \gls 1SG.SBJ begin IPFV RED.CPD-cut.up 1PL fry potato 1PL fry plantain | \glt ‘I began to (repeatedly) snip [the trimmings], we fried potatoes, we fried plantain.’

Knowledge Point: Pichi exhibits a phonologically conditioned suppletive allomorphy in the pronominal system. The lexical pitch configuration of a verb determines the choice of allomorph used for the expression of \textsc{3sg} pronominal object case (cf. \sectref{sec:3.2.5}). Vowel-final verbs with a word-final low tone take the object pronoun ín ‘\textsc{3sg.indp}’ – this group includes a few Pichi verbs and all inserted Spanish verbs \REF{ex:key:1713}. This is because the \textsc{3sg} invariant form of the Equatoguinean Spanish verb always features a word-final L-toned vowel:
Content 1: \gll Fíba nó \textbf{sube} ín. | \gls fever NEG go.up 3SG.INDP | \glt ‘The fever hasn’t risen on him.’

Knowledge Point: In a similar vein, the verbs sube (<subir) ‘go up’ and baja (<bajar) ‘go down’ are far more frequent than their Pichi counterparts gó ɔ́p and gó dɔ́n \REF{ex:key:1715}: \is{loan words}
Content 1: \gll Bɔkú motó dɛn dé yá só, a nó nó sé Pancho mék lɛk sé e de \textbf{sube} bihɛ́n wé e \textbf{baja} mɔ́. | \gls much car PL BE.LOC here like.that 1SG.SBJ NEG know QUOT NAME make like QUOT 3SG.SBJ IPFV go.up behind SUB 3SG.SBJ go.down more | \glt ‘So many cars were there, I didn’t know Pancho pretended to go up behind us (and) went down again.’

Knowledge Point: Spanish adjectives do not only occur as attributes to Pichi nouns. They are systematically inserted into Pichi predicate adjective clauses as complements to the locative-existential copula\is{copula!locative-existential} dé \textsc{‘be.loc’} \REF{ex:key:1716}.
Content 1: \gll Wán yáy \textbf{dé} \textbf{blanco} e nó de sí. | \gls one eye BE.LOC white 3SG.SBJ NEG IPFV see | \glt ‘One eye is white, it doesn’t see.’

Knowledge Point: Neither adjectives nor past participles usually exhibit Spanish-style gender agreement with the subject and are normally inserted in the masculine form. However, past participles always come along with the regular Spanish adjective-deriving morphology \REF{ex:key:1717}.
Content 1: \gll \MakeUppercase{A} wánt dé \textbf{flipa}-\textbf{do} ɔ́l áwa, ɔ́l áwa. | \gls 1SG.SBJ want BE.LOC turned.on-ADJ all hour all hour | \glt ‘I want to be turned on all the time, all the time.’

Knowledge Point: I have shown that a handful of Pichi property items may be employed as adjectives and inchoative-stative verbs alike (cf. \sectref{sec:7.6.5}). When used as adjectives, these property items denote a non-time-stable body state\is{body states} and may appear as complements to the copula dé. When used as inchoative-stative verbs, these property items denote a time-stable value. The property item bád ‘be bad’ displays this kind of behaviour. Hence, bád means ‘(intrinsically) bad’ \REF{ex:key:1718} when used as an inchoative-stative verb and ‘ill’ when it appears as a complement to the copula dé \REF{ex:key:1719}:
Content 1: \gll Sɔn mamá dɛn, dɛn \textbf{bád.} | \gls some mother PL 3PL be.bad | \glt ‘Some mothers, they are bad.’
Content 2: \gll "E \textbf{dé} \textbf{bád}" min sé "e de sík". | \gls 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC bad mean QUOT 3SG.SBJ IPFV be.sick | \glt ‘“E dé bad” means “he’s sick”.’

Knowledge Point: Spanish also exhibits a distinction based on time-stability with respect to property items. In contrast to Pichi, the distinction may, however, be applied to almost any adjective of the language. Examples \REF{ex:key:1720} and \REF{ex:key:1721} involve the \textsc{3sg} present form of the time-stable identity copula ser and the \textsc{2sg} present of the non-time-stable locative-existential copula estar, respectively. A comparison of the Pichi examples in \REF{ex:key:1718} and \REF{ex:key:1719} above with the two sentences below show the functional overlap of the relevant constructions in the two languages:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll Sɔn mamá dɛn, dɛn \textbf{bád.} | \gls some mother PL 3PL be.bad | \glt ‘Some mothers, they are bad.’
Content 4: \gll "E \textbf{dé} \textbf{bád}" min sé "e de sík". | \gls 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC bad mean QUOT 3SG.SBJ IPFV be.sick | \glt ‘“E dé bad” means “he’s sick”.’

Knowledge Point: Hence the time-stable property denoted by the Spanish adjective blanco ‘white’ appears as a complement to the copula dé in \REF{ex:key:1716} above, while the Pichi colour term wáyt ‘be white’ can only be employed as a inchoative-stative verb as in \REF{ex:key:1722}:
Content 1: \gll Wán yáy \textbf{dé} \textbf{blanco} e nó de sí. | \gls one eye BE.LOC white 3SG.SBJ NEG IPFV see | \glt ‘One eye is white, it doesn’t see.’
Content 2: \gll Di mán \textbf{wáyt}. | \gls DEF man be.white | \glt ‘The man is white.’

Knowledge Point: The most frequently used Spanish functional elements are the cause clause linkers como ‘since’ \REF{ex:key:1723} and porque ‘because’ \REF{ex:key:1724}. Both linkers form an integral part of the Pichi system of clause linkage and are best seen to have been borrowed into the language:\is{loan words}
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Como} wí de kɔ́l=an \textbf{mono} na Panyá, ín chɛ́k=an sé ɛf e tɔ́k sé wán mɔnkí, e go dé fáyn. | \gls since 1PL.INDP IPFV call=3SG.OBJ monkey LOC Spanish 3SG.INDP think=3SG.OBJ QUOT if 3SG.SBJ talk QUOT one monkey 3SG.SBJ POT BE.LOC fine | \glt ‘Since we [EMP] call it “mono” in Spanish, he [EMP] understood it such that if he said “one monkey”, it would be all right.’
Content 2: \gll Yu nɛ́a gɛ́t pikín \textbf{porque} yu nɛ́a máred. | \gls 2SG NEG.PRF get child because 2SG NEG.PRF marry | \glt ‘You don’t yet have a child, because you aren’t yet married.’

Knowledge Point: The linkers como and porque are employed in the same syntactic position as the Pichi equivalents as ‘as’ \REF{ex:key:1725} and bikɔs ‘because’ \REF{ex:key:1726}, respectively:
Content 1: \gll 'As in sísta dɛn bin de kɔ́l in mamá sé sísta, in de kɔ́l in mamá sé sísta. | \gls as 3SG.POSS sister 3PL PST IPFV call 3SG.POSS mother QUOT sister 3SG.INDP IPFV call 3SG.POSS mother QUOT sister | \glt ‘As her sisters would call her mother sister, she [EMP] would call her mother sister.’
Content 2: \gll Bɛt a dɔ́n nó wétin yu níd, \textbf{bikɔs} wi gɛ́t sɔn prɔ́blɛm wé wi de tɔ́k Pichi na Malábo. | \gls but 1SG.SBJ PRF NEG what 2SG need because 1PL get some problem SUB 1PL IPFV talk Pichi LOC PLACE | \glt ‘But I already know what you need, because we have a problem when we talk Pichi in Malabo.’

Knowledge Point: The clause linker aunque ‘although’ occurs so frequently that it is best seen to be fully integrated into the Pichi lexicon as well. In Spanish too, aunque is used both as a concessive\is{concessive clauses} or adversative conjunction as in \REF{ex:key:1727} and as a a similative\is{similatives} adverbial as in \REF{ex:key:1728}:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Wé yu de mék=an na hós, jɔ́s ték=an, pút=an na pɔ́t \textbf{aunque} wán \textbf{taza} só. | \gls SUB 2SG IPFV make=3SG.OBJ LOC house just take=3SG.OBJ put=3SG.OBJ LOC pot like one cup like.that | \glt ‘When you make it at home, just take it (and) put it into a pot, like one cup or so.’

Knowledge Point: The Spanish coordinator pair ni – ni ‘neither – nor, not even’ can express negative disjunction in Pichi utterances. Like in Spanish, ni can be used alone \REF{ex:key:1730} or in discontinuous negation\is{negation} \REF{ex:key:1731}. Unlike in Spanish, however, subject disjunction in Pichi requires the kind of negative concord characteristic of other negative clauses in Pichi \REF{ex:key:1731}:
Content 1: \gll E nó sabí tɔ́k \textbf{ni} Panyá, e sé e wánt \textbf{muchachita} \textbf{de} \textbf{diecisiete} \textbf{años}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ NEG know talk neither Spanish 3SG.SBJ QUOT 3SG.SBJ want young.girl of seventeen year.PL | \glt ‘He doesn’t even know how to speak Spanish, (and) he says he wants a girl of seventeen years.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ni} ín \textbf{ni} in brɔ́da dɛn \textbf{nó} lán. | \gls neither 3SG.INDP neither 3SG.POSS brother 3PL NEG learn | \glt ‘Neither him nor his brother studied.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Ni} ín \textbf{ni} in brɔ́da dɛn \textbf{nó} lán. | \gls neither 3SG.INDP neither 3SG.POSS brother 3PL NEG learn | \glt ‘Neither him nor his brother studied.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:1732}, we find the cardinal numeral wán ‘one’ in a peculiar construction with the meaning ‘around’ in combination with quantity expressions. When wán is employed in this way, it usually modifies \textsc{NPs} containing numerals \REF{ex:key:1732} and time units \REF{ex:key:1733}:
Content 1: \gll Yu jɔ́s gɛ́t wán \textbf{diecisiete} \textbf{años}. | \gls 2SG just get one seventeen year.PL | \glt ‘You’re just about seventeen years old.’
Content 2: \gll Yu jɔ́s gɛ́t wán \textbf{diecisiete} \textbf{años}. | \gls 2SG just get one seventeen year.PL | \glt ‘You’re just about seventeen years old.’
Content 3: \gll Tumɔ́ro mɔ́nin tɛ́n,t wán \textbf{las} \textbf{siete} só, a go gó dé. | \gls tomorrow morning time one the.PL seven like.that 1SG.SBJ POT go there | \glt ‘Tomorrow in the morning, around seven or so, I will go there.’

Knowledge Point: I attribute this particular usage of the numeral wán to structural borrowing from Spanish. In Spanish, the plural indefinite articles unos, unas serve the same function \REF{ex:key:1734}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Spanish discourse markers and adverbs frequently occur at the beginning of a sentence. Speakers often use Spanish material that is not syntactically integrated into a Pichi clause structure. This includes the high frequency adverbs bueno ‘well’ \REF{ex:key:1735} and pero ‘but’ \REF{ex:key:1736}. Conversely, the interjection chico ‘boy’ \REF{ex:key:1736} is not common in European Spanish. It might have developed in Equatoguinean Spanish and Pichi through mutual reinforcement and calquing of other person-denoting interjections in Pichi and other Equatoguinean languages.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Bueno}, so e kán tɛ́l mí sé na tidé. | \gls well so 3SG.SBJ PFV tell 1SG.INDP QUOT FOC today | \glt ‘Well, so she told me that it was today.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The interjection chico ‘boy’ in \REF{ex:key:1736} above is more common than other human-denoting Pichi equivalents such as mán ‘man’, papá \textit{\textup{‘father’,} }or mamá ‘mother’. The Spanish noun mierda ‘shit’ is very common as a deprecative interjection \REF{ex:key:1737}:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Mierda} \textbf{mierda}, ús=sáy e pás? | \gls shit REP Q=side 3SG.SBJ pass | \glt ‘Shit, shit, which way did she go?’

Knowledge Point: The Spanish focus syntagma es que ‘it is that’ may also be seen as a peripheral element which constitutes an independent syntactic unit \REF{ex:key:1740}. However, es que is so much an integral part of the Pichi system of focus marking that it seems like a holophrastic borrowing\is{borrowing} (cf. \sectref{sec:7.4.3} for more). Also note the interesting switch to Spanish at the clausal boundary between the relative clause and the following main clause.
Content 1: \gll Es que húman wé e gɛ́t bɛlɛ́ \textbf{siempre} \textbf{suele} \textbf{ser} \textbf{así}. | \gls It.is that woman SUB 3SG.SBJ get belly always usually be like.that | \glt ‘It’s that women who are pregnant are always like that.’

Knowledge Point: When telling the time, Spanish lexical items are fit into a conventionalised mixed construction which does not have an exact equivalent in Spanish. In the Pichi construction, the clock time is an adverbial complement to the locative-existential copula\is{copula!locative-existential} dé ‘\textsc{cop’}. The copula, in turn, takes the \textsc{1pl} subject wi \REF{ex:key:1743}. In the Spanish construction, the clock time functions as the subject of the identity copula ser ‘be’ \REF{ex:key:1743}:
Content 1: \gll Son \textbf{las} \textbf{cuatro} \textbf{y} \textbf{media}. | \gls They.are the.PL four and half | \glt ‘It’s four thirty.’
Content 2: \gll Son \textbf{las} \textbf{cuatro} \textbf{y} \textbf{media}. | \gls They.are the.PL four and half | \glt ‘It’s four thirty.’

Knowledge Point: Equally, the majority of speakers employ Spanish dates\is{loan words}. One of the few tokens of a date featuring Pichi numerals was produced by a lady of more than eighty years of age \REF{ex:key:1745}. I assume this instance and the few other similar ones in the corpus to be holophrastic insertions. This view is supported by the fact that the date in \REF{ex:key:1745} is the speaker’s date of birth and perhaps just as significantly, she was married to a Nigerian in her youth. Other than that, this speaker’s use of numerals parallels the one outlined in \tabref{tab:key:13.4} above:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Most speakers are not familiar with Pichi day names and employ the Spanish day nomenclature \REF{ex:key:1746}. Even older speakers rarely if ever use the corresponding Pichi day names mɔ́nde ‘Monday’, tyúsde ‘Tuesday’, wɛ́nsde ‘Wednesday’, tɔsde ‘Thursday’, frayde ‘Friday’, sátidé ‘Saturday’, and sɔ́nde ‘Sunday’ \REF{ex:key:1747}:
Content 1: \gll Dí \textbf{miércoles} a de gó Lubá. | \gls this Wednesday 1SG.SBJ IPFV go PLACE.’ | \glt ‘This Wednesday, I am going to Luba.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Lunes} na mɔ́nde, tyúsde wé na \textbf{martes}. | \gls monday FOC Monday tuesday SUB FOC tuesday | \glt ‘“Lunes” is Monday. Tuesday that’s “martes”.’

Knowledge Point: The elicitation of Pichi day names with two speakers below twenty-eight years was unsuccessful save sɔ́nde ‘Sunday’, certainly because of its social importance for religious practice. A speaker above fifty-five years experienced considerable difficulties in retrieving Pichi day names (\ref{ex:key:1748a}–c). Wɛ́nsde ‘Wednesday’ was only retrieved after an external input (b) and the elicitation of ‘Thursday’ and ‘Friday’ produced the misnomers tyúsde ‘Tuesday’ (c) and wɛ́nsde ‘Wednesday’ (d), respectively:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Miercoles} na, áy, pero a sabí=an. | \gls wednesday FOC INTJ but 1SG.SBJ know=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘"Wednesday" is, ah [pause], but I know it.’

Knowledge Point: In contrast, Pichi designations for the seasons of the year are fully in use, as shown by the use of the compound noun ren-sísin ‘rainy season’ \REF{ex:key:1749} and amatán ‘harmattan’ in \REF{ex:key:1750}:
Content 1: \gll Dís dé dɛn ren-sísin go bigín. | \gls this day PL rainy.CPD{}-season POT begin | \glt ‘These days, the rainy season should begin.’
Content 2: \gll Wi de kɔ́l yá só amatán dán, lɛkɛ sé e kin dé lɛkɛ \textbf{niebla}. | \gls 1PL IPFV call here like.that harmattan that like QUOT 3SG.SBJ HAB BE.LOC like fog | \glt ‘Here, we call harmattan that, like it’s usually like fog.’

Knowledge Point: Many West African languages, including basilectal Nigerian Pidgin \citep[286]{Faraclas1996} express colours and hues other than ‘black’ and ‘white’ through periphrasis, suprasegmentals and ideophones\is{ideophones}. We also find the expression of colours through periphrasis in Pichi, as in \REF{ex:key:1751} and \REF{ex:key:1752}.
Content 1: \gll Di bɔ́y \textbf{yɛ́lo} lɛkɛ Chici. | \gls DEF boy be.yellow like NAME | \glt ‘The guy is yellow like [the guy called] Chici.’
Content 2: \gll Dán tín \textbf{yɛ́lo} lɛk banána. | \gls that thing be.yellow like banana | \glt ‘That thing is yellow like a banana.’

Knowledge Point: When Spanish colour terms are used attributively, they occur with Spanish head nouns \REF{ex:key:1753}. The corpus contains no examples of mixed collocations involving a Spanish colour denoting property item and a Pichi head noun:
Content 1: \gll A tínk sé na \textbf{judías} \textbf{blancas} o no sé. | \gls 1SG.SBJ think QUOT FOC bean.PL white.PL or NEG I.know | \glt ‘I think they’re white beans or so.’

Knowledge Point: Other semantic fields characterised by a high incidence of codemixing involve formalised, institutional domains. One of the few Pichi country names in use is Panyá ‘Spain’, the designation for the former colonial power. Spanish lexemes are exclusively employed for country names like Guinea (Ecuatorial) ‘Equatorial Guinea’, Gabón ‘Gabon’ \REF{ex:key:1754}, ethnonyms like europeo ‘European’ or cameruneses ‘Cameroonians’ \REF{ex:key:1755}, as well as terms belonging to the state domain such as problema diplomático ‘diplomatic problem’ \REF{ex:key:1754}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Entonces} wán \textbf{problema} \textbf{diplomático} kán dé entre \textbf{Guinea} wet \textbf{Gabón}. | \gls so one problem diplomatic PFV BE.LOC between PLACE with PLACE | \glt ‘So a diplomatic problem came to be between Guinea and Gabon.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Cameruneses}, yɛ́s dɛn plɛ́nte yá. | \gls Cameroonians yes 3PL be.plenty here | \glt ‘Cameroonians, yes they are many here.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Entonces} wán \textbf{problema} \textbf{diplomático} kán dé entre \textbf{Guinea} wet \textbf{Gabón}. | \gls so one problem diplomatic PFV BE.LOC between PLACE with PLACE | \glt ‘So a diplomatic problem came to be between Guinea and Gabon.’

Knowledge Point: Also compare the Spanish terms registro ‘(civil) registry’ and registra ‘(to) register’ in \REF{ex:key:1756}:
Content 1: \gll A bin gɛ́fɔ chénch in ném na \textbf{registro} a \textbf{registra} ín. | \gls 1SG.SBJ PST have.to change 3SG.POSS NAME LOC register 1SG.SBJ register 3SG.INDP | \glt ‘I had to change her name in the register, I registered her.’

Knowledge Point: The Pichi lexemes skul ‘school’, gɔ́bna ‘government’ \REF{ex:key:1757}, and chɔ́ch ‘church’ \REF{ex:key:1758} designate these institutions in their general sense and are favoured over their Spanish equivalents escuela, gobierno, and iglesia:
Content 1: \gll E de gó fɔ, sɔn \textbf{skúl} wé dé fɔ \textbf{gɔ́bna}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ IPFV go PREP some school SUB BE.LOC PREP government | \glt ‘She goes to a school that belongs to government.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Meanwhile, the incidence of Spanish lexemes rises with the degree of specificity of words within the semantic fields designated by these superordinates. Thus, we have catedral ‘cathedral’ in \REF{ex:key:1758} above, bolí ‘pen’ and cuaderno ‘exercise book’ \REF{ex:key:1759}, as well as profe(sor) ‘teacher’ – though tícha ‘teacher’ is also common, however less so beyond primary school.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Wé, yu wánt báy \textbf{cuaderno}, \textbf{bolí} ɔ́l dán tín dɛn na wet \textbf{dólar}. | \gls SUB 2SG want buy exercise.book pen all that thing PL FOC with dollar | \glt ‘While, if you want to buy exercise books, pens, all those things are with the dollar.’

Knowledge Point: The preponderance of Spanish lexemes in other semantic fields reflects the asymmetric power relation that holds between Pichi and Spanish in a different way. For example, semantic fields relating to illness and medical treatment that are highly differentiated in other languages of the region (e.g. \ili{Yoruba}, see \citet{Adegbite1993}) probably did not assert itself in Pichi due to the marginalisation of African medical science with the advent of colonialism. In \REF{ex:key:1761}, we therefore find placenta ‘placenta’ and matriz ‘womb’ for which only the general term bɛlɛ́ ‘belly, womb’ is recorded and Spanish membrano ‘membrane’ which has no equivalent in Pichi:
Content 1: \gll Wé dɔ́kta ópin, wé dɛn bigín drɔ́ di, sɔn tín we e kin dé bihɛ́n \textbf{placenta}, na \textbf{membrana}, sɔn kán lɛ́f bifó di \textbf{matriz}, so di \textbf{matriz} nó kán lɔ́k. | \gls SUB doctor open SUB 3PL begin draw DEF some thing SUB 3SG.SBJ HAB BE.LOC behind placenta FOC membrane some PFV remain before DEF womb so DEF womb NEG PFV lock | \glt ‘When the doctor opened (the womb), they began to draw out the, a certain thing that is usually behind the placenta, it’s a membrane, some remained in front of the womb, so the womb didn’t close.’

Knowledge Point: The systematic use of Spanish items also occurs in semantic fields that designate aspects of material and non-material culture of external origin. In \REF{ex:key:1762}, a car mechanic explains the disadvantages of an Opel ignition cable. Note the Spanish technical terms in the sentence:
Content 1: \gll Hɛ́, a go fála yú bikɔs sɔn \textbf{cable} dé wé na fɔ Opel, yu \textbf{intenta} bríng Opel in yón na \textbf{corriente}, Opel de kɛ́r bɔkú \textbf{corriente} só e nó go fít ɛ́nta na dán \textbf{bujía}, yu go wánda sɛ́f.\\ | \gls INTJ 1SG.SBJ POT accompany 2SG.INDP because some cable BE.LOC SUB FOC PREP NAME 2SG try bring NAME 3SG.POSS own FOC electricity NAME IPFV take much electricity like.that 3SG.SBJ NEG POT can enter LOC that ignition.plug 2SG POT wonder EMP | \glt ‘Hey, I’ll accompany you because there’s a cable which is an Opel (cable), (and if) you try to connect the Opel one with electricity, Opel takes a lot of electricity, so it won’t be able to enter that ignition plug, (and) you’ll be very surprised.’

Knowledge Point: Spanish kinship\is{kinship terminology} terms have also left their mark on the language (cf. also \sectref{sec:12.3}). In \REF{ex:key:1763}, we find primo ‘(male) cousin’, a kinship concept that is only rarely expressed by the Pichi term kɔsín.
Content 1: \gll A tínk sé dɛn papá na mi mamá in \textbf{primo}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ think QUOT 3PL father FOC 1SG.POSS mother 3SG.POSS cousin | \glt ‘I think that their father is my mother’s cousin.’

Knowledge Point: Conversely, the incidence of Spanish words is low in semantic fields characterised by the use of autochthonous technology, such as farming and with designations for locally-grown foodstuffs and other flora. Thus, in \REF{ex:key:1764}, we have díg grɔ́n ‘dig ground’ = ‘plough up the ground’, plánt chɔ́p ‘(to) plant food’, gádin ‘small field, garden’, jakató ‘bitter tomato’ and kíp ‘grow, rear’, as well as pamáyn ‘oil’, and gadinɛ́ks ‘egg-plant’ \REF{ex:key:1765}:
Content 1: \gll A díg grɔ́n, a plánt chɔ́p, a gó na gádin, a kíp jakató, verdura. | \gls 1SG.SBJ dig ground 1SG.SBJ plant food 1SG.SBJ go FOC garden 1SG.SBJ grow bitter.tomato vegetables | \glt ‘I ploughed the ground, I planted food, I went to the garden, I grew bitter tomato, vegetables.’
Content 2: \gll Di dé wé yu go níd=an, yu go sé a nó gɛ́t \textbf{pamáyn}, yu go kɔ́t \textbf{gadinɛ́ks}. | \gls DEF day SUB 2SG POT need=3SG.OBJ 2SG POT QUOT 1SG.SBJ NEG get oil 2SG POT cut egg.plant | \glt ‘The day when you would need it, you would say “I don’t have oil”, (and) you would harvest egg-plants.’
